Award.AwardTitle: CAS: Lignocellulosic building blocks towards high-performance and sustainable polysulfones and polyurethanes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polyurethanes are ubiquitous in a range of consumer products from athletic goods to automotive parts, showcasing their versatility to address a variety of application needs. Typically manufactured utilizing petroleum feedstocks, the continued use of polymers, such as a polyurethanes, is impacted by questions around recyclability and environmental impacts. The transformation of biomass into value-added polymers is a promising route to develop materials with comparable performance and lower cost, and that can be designed for an optimal product lifecycle. Utilizing wood biomass, the team will design, synthesize, and characterize high-performance polymers, investigate more sustainable approaches to the generation of polymers, and study the influence of wood diversity on material properties and environmental impact. These bioderived polymers have potential applications as membranes, elastomers, and foams.

Sustainability in the context of new materials design will be leveraged as a framework for broadening participation in science and engineering fields at all levels -– K-12, undergraduate, graduate, and aspiring faculty -- via strategic partnerships, mentoring activities, and educational activities. High school internships and research opportunities will prepare underrepresented students for science and engineering college pathways. Mentoring activities for female graduate students and post-docs will be implemented, focusing on shared experiences and sustained dialogue. Diversifying the professoriate with a focus on soft materials will be targeted via an annual workshop, expanded to include concepts of collaborative, multidisciplinary research.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Alternative synthetic approaches are critical for the utilization of biomass building blocks in the development of robust polymeric materials with exceptional mechanical function and thermal properties. Lignocellulosic biomass, particularly the lignin fraction, is an attractive source of diverse, abundant, and inexpensive precursors for macromolecular design. Bisguaiacols, such as the newly-developed bisguaiacol A (BGA) –- an entirely bio-based, methoxy-substituted analogue to bisphenol A (BPA) -- are robust and potentially safer components for the design of polymeric systems with enhanced properties. Utilizing lignin-based biomass as a primary synthetic precursor, the PIs will investigate the following strategies in the design of sustainable routes for bio-based polymeric materials – polysulfones (PSFs) and polyurethanes (PUs) with enhanced material properties: (i) synthesis of new bisguaiacol analogues for BPA-replacements for polymerization; (ii) development of schemes for ‘green’ PU synthesis; (iii) exploration of the influence of biomass source on thermomechanical behavior; (iv) construction of structure-property-processing relationships; (v) toxicity assessment of these bisguaiacol-based polymers; (vi) examination of reprocessability in bisguaiacol-derived PU networks; and (vii) exploration of additive manufacturing conditions and post-functionalize strategies for scale-up. Expertise in materials science, polymer chemistry, and chemical engineering will drive this fundamental research program that spans the inclusion of diverse lignin sources, synthesis of sustainable building blocks, macromolecular design and characterization, and manufacturing of ‘green’ polymers for a diverse set of applications.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The continued use of petroleum-derived feedstocks for polymer synthesis and potential associated health and environmental aspects of these building blocks, motivate the utilization of sustainable routes and feedstocks to reimagine polymer design, focusing on comparable performance and optimal product lifecycle. The major aim of this “Critical Aspects of Sustainability” project in the Division of Materials Research Polymer program was the design of high-performance polymers, such as polyurethanes (PUs) and polysulfones (PSfs), using (lignin-rich) wood biomass, aromatic building blocks, investigating the influence of wood diversity on material properties and health impacts towards coatings, membranes, and foam applications. Toward this aim, research activities spanned (1) synthesis and toxicity assessment of biomass-derivable aromatic precursors, (2) the development of efficient and sustainable schemes for bio-derivable polymer synthesis, (3) the examination of the impact of inherent structural features in biomass-derivable feedstocks on performance and processability, and (4) the exploration of strategies to promote circularity and manage the materials at end of life. These specific tasks leveraged materials science, polymer chemistry, and chemical engineering expertise to enable synthesis of sustainable building blocks, polymer design and characterization, manufacturing of ‘green’ polymers for a diverse set of applications, team science, and educational programming. Overall, this research project made significant advances in the development of structure-property-processing relationships to enable tuning of the polymer strength and toughness and application-specific function of biomass-derivable thermoplastics and thermosets including: the realization of polymer design pathways to meet or exceed the performance of petroleum-derived analogs, proof-of-concept strategies to reprocess biomass-derivable networks over multiple cycles with minimal property losses, and new insights into the utilization of the inherent chemical diversity of lignin-rich biomass for sustainable and efficient coatings and fiber manufacturing. 

Intellectual Merit

Lignin-derivable bisphenols were synthesized and screened for utilization as building blocks for sustainable polymer design and drop-in replacement for current technologies. Specifically, synthetic schemes for sustainable PUs and PSfs were designed to address key challenges related to reducing reliance on petroleum feedstocks, minimizing environmental and health impacts, and maximizing desirable processing and performance characteristics. Several classes of high value polymers (thermoplastics and thermosets) were synthesized, characterization, and processed to probe the impact of the chemical diversity of these biomass-derivable, aromatic precursors on mechanical, thermal, and flow behavior and to benchmark their performance against petroleum-derived analogs. These fundamental and innovative investigations necessitated the integration of polymer science and engineering, modeling, molecular engineering, hierarchical characterization techniques, and materials manufacturing. One illustration of project success was the development of a suite of sustainable, lignin-derivable, thermoplastics that displayed enhanced toughness and extensibility, met or exceeded relevant benchmarks (thermal stability, tensile strength) against control materials, and exhibited favorable processing characteristics critical for product manufacturing. Building upon these achievements, another example of scientific advancement is the manufacture of lignin-derivable thermosets that revealed the interplay of molecular features, architecture, and dynamic behavior to achieve tunable thermal and mechanical properties and realize circularity for end-of-life management. These innovations also motivated adjacent, proof-of-concept studies to valorize traditional PUs. An additional instance of project translation was the collaborative (Arizona State University) demonstration that inherent chemical features of lignin-derivable building blocks endowed increased polarity and resulting hydrophilicity to PSfs (while maintaining thermal stability) without the typical post-synthetic modification necessary for water filtration applications. Altogether, these examples of project innovations showcase the utility of woody biomass as a versatile and robust building block to derive performance-advantaged polymer materials and advance understanding of life cycle management. 

Broader Impacts

Beyond the exciting scientific advances in sustainable materials design and manufacturing, the major findings from this project were disseminated in peer-reviewed journals; translated to intellectual property filings; communicated via oral and poster presentations at conferences, workshops, and industrial visits; and utilized in the development of education and outreach activities.  This research project impacted emerging and longstanding topics in polymer science and engineering related to architecture, fabrication, assembly, and mechanical tunability within the context of sustainability, circularity, AND performance. This sustainable materials design framework was leveraged to broaden participation in science and engineering fields at all levels – K-12, undergraduate, graduate, and aspiring faculty - via strategic partnerships, mentoring activities, and educational activities. Graduate students and postdoctoral students engaged in this project served as high school and undergraduate research mentors, advanced sustainability via symposium organization at National conferences, and developed interdisciplinary, convergent skills in sustainable polymer design. These trainees were recognized with several recognitions of their scientific achievements, including the 2024 Thermoset Resins Formulators Association Excellence in Thermoset Polymer Research Award and the 2024 ACS POLY Excellence in Graduate Polymer Research Symposium, Top Oral Presenter Award. Additionally, project personnel delivered lectures and policy briefings, participated in annual outreach events, shared career advice and green principles at local high schools, and developed and/or participated in programming related to improving graduate student mental health and well-being and enhancing diversity in the chemical sciences. 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Lashanda T Korley
